{{also|Normal|normál}} ==English== {{wikipedia}} ===Etymology=== From {{der|en|la|normālis||made according to a carpenter's square; ''later:'' according to a rule}}, from {{m|la|nōrma||carpenter's square}}, of uncertain origin.{{R:MWO}}{{R:Dictionary.com}}{{R:Etymonline}}{{R:Century 1911}} The earliest use of the word in English was to mean "perpendicular; forming a right angle" like something {{m|la|normālis||made according to a carpenter's square}},''The Merriam-Webster New Book of Word Histories'' (1991, {{ISBN|0877796033}}), age 321 but by Latin Latin {{m|la|normālis}} had also come to mean "according to a rule", from which modern English senses of the word derive: in the 1800s, as people began to quantitatively study things like height and weight and blood pressure, the usual or most common values came to be referred to as "normal", and by extension values regarded as healthy or desirable came to be called "normal" regardless of their usuality.Brent Davis, Dennis Sumara, ''Complexity and Education'' (2014, {{ISBN|1134815786}}) ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|UK}} {{IPA|en|/ˈnɔːməl/}} * {{a|US}} {{IPA|en|/ˈnɔɹməl/}} * {{rhymes|en|ɔː(ɹ)məl}} * {{audio|en|en-us-normal.ogg|Audio (GA)}} ===Adjective=== {{en-adj|er|more}} # According to [[norm]]s or rules or to a [[regular]] pattern. #: {{ux|en|Organize the data into third normal form.}} #* '''2007''', Steven Wilson, "Normal", Porcupine Tree, ''Nil Recurring''. #*:{{quote|en|Prescription drugs, they help me through the day / And that restraining order keeps me well at bay / And what's '''normal''' now, anyway?}} #* '''2014''', Michael Rush, ''Politics & Society'', Routledge ({{ISBN|9781317866992}}), page 210: #*: In other words, although the legal processes were observed, it was not a '''normal''' transfer of power within each of the ruling communist parties. {{...|Rather than relying solely on the presence of violence or the threat of it by opponents of the regime, [...It was] brought about by abnormal means[. ...]}} Demonstrations of the sort that brought about the collapse of the communist regimes in Eastern Europe were nor '''normal''', and where attempts had previously been made to hold them, they were invariably suppressed by force. ## {{lb|en|mathematics}} Adhering to or being what is considered natural or regular in a particular field or context: ### {{lb|en|of a real number}} Whose digits, in any base representation, enjoy a uniform distribution. ### {{lb|en|algebra|of a subgroup}} With [[coset]]s which form a group. ### {{lb|en|algebra|of a field extension of a field K}} Which is the splitting field of a family of polynomials in K. ### {{lb|en|probability theory|statistics|of a distribution}} Which has a very specific [[bell curve]] shape; that is or has the qualities of a [[normal distribution]]. ### {{lb|en|probability theory|statistics|of a random variable, etc.}} Which has a [[normal distribution]]; which is associated with [[random variable]] that has a normal distribution. ### {{lb|en|complex analysis|of a family of continuous functions}} Which is [[pre-compact]]. ### {{lb|en|set theory|of a function from the ordinals to the ordinals}} Which is strictly monotonically increasing and continuous with respect to the order topology. ### {{lb|en|linear algebra|of a matrix}} Which commutes with its conjugate transpose. ### {{lb|en|functional analysis|of a Hilbert space operator}} Which commutes with its adjoint. ### {{lb|en|category theory}} Being (as a morphism) or containing (as a category) only normal epimorphism(s) or monomorphism(s), that is, those which are the [[kernel]] or [[cokernel]] of some [[morphism]], respectively. ### {{lb|en|topology|of a topology}} In which disjoint closed sets can be separated by disjoint neighborhoods. # Usual, healthy; not sick or ill or unlike onself. #: {{ux|en|John is feeling normal again.}} # {{lb|en|education|of a school}} teaching teachers how to teach {{q|to certain norms}} #: {{ux|en|My grandmother attended Mankato State Normal School.}} # {{lb|en|chemistry}} Of, relating to, or being a [[solution]] containing one [[equivalent weight]] of [[solute]] per [[litre]] of [[solution]]. # {{lb|en|organic chemistry}} Describing a [[straight chain]] [[isomer]] of an [[aliphatic]] [[hydrocarbon]], or an aliphatic compound in which a [[substituent]] is in the 1- position of such a hydrocarbon. # {{lb|en|physics|of a mode in an oscillating system}} In which all parts of an object [[vibrate]] at the same [[frequency]] {{qualifier|see ''[[w:normal mode|normal mode]]''}}. # {{lb|en|rail transport|of points}} In the default position, set for the most frequently used route. # {{lb|en|geometry}} Perpendicular to a [[tangent]] of a curve or [[derivative]] of a surface. #* The interior normal vector of an ideal perfect sphere will always point toward the center, and the exterior normal vector directly away, and both will always be co-linear with the ray whose' tip ends at the point of intersection, which is the intersection of all three sets of points. ====Usage notes==== * Warning: ''normal'', when used to describe a majority group of people, can be offensive to those who do not consider membership of a minority to be unusual. Care should be taken when juxtaposing normal, particularly with stereotypical labels, to avoid undue insult. ====Synonyms==== * {{sense|usual}} {{l|en|conventional}}, {{l|en|customary}}, {{l|en|ordinary}}, {{l|en|standard}}, {{l|en|usual}}, {{l|en|regular}}, {{l|en|routine}}, {{l|en|average}}, {{l|en|expected}}, {{l|en|natural}}, {{l|en|typical}}, {{l|en|everyday}}, {{l|en|common}}, {{l|en|commonplace}}, {{l|en|general}} * {{sense|healthy}} {{l|en|hale}}, {{l|en|healthy}}, {{l|en|well}} * {{sense|perpendicular}} at [[right angle]]s to, [[perpendicular]], [[orthogonal]] * {{sense|statistics}} {{l|en|Gaussian}}, {{l|en|standard normal}} ====Antonyms==== * {{sense|usual}} {{l|en|unconventional}}, {{l|en|nonstandard}}, {{l|en|unusual}} * {{sense|healthy}} {{l|en|ill}}, {{l|en|poorly}} {{qualifier|British}}, [[sick]], [[unwell]] * {{sense|perpendicular}} {{l|en|tangential}} * {{sense|rail transport}} {{l|en|reverse}} ====Derived terms==== surface, or [[plane]]. # {{lb|en|slang|countable}} A person who is normal, who fits into [[mainstream]] society, as opposed to those who live [[alternative lifestyle]]s. # {{lb|en|uncountable}} The [[usual]] [[state]]. #: {{ux|en|His workload is now back to '''normal'''.}} #: {{ux|en|Heavy workload is the new '''normal'''.}} ====Synonyms==== * {{sense|normal person}} see
